importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Ali Danial Hemani was indicted in 2023 on a count of violating the guns-and-drugs law after marijuana and cocaine were found at his home.
Hunter Biden was convicted in 2024 under the same federal law and later pardoned by President Joe Biden.
A landmark Supreme Court decision in 2022 made it easier for Americans to carry handguns in public and set a precedent requiring gun prohibitions to have historical roots.
The case references the 2020 US drone strike that killed Qasem Soleimani, an Iranian official, which is tied to allegations in Hemani’s case regarding travel to Iran.
The Supreme Court agreed to review the constitutionality of the federal law banning drug users from possessing guns on October 20, 2025.

keyTakeAways: The Supreme Court agreed to review a federal law that bans certain drug users from possessing firearms, raising constitutional questions about the Second Amendment.

The case centers on Ali Danial Hemani, a dual US-Pakistani citizen, who was indicted in 2023 for possessing a firearm along with marijuana and cocaine, with prosecutors claiming his habitual drug use.
A federal district court dismissed the charge, citing a 2022 Supreme Court precedent that requires gun prohibitions to be historically rooted.
The 5th Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the 2022 precedent, ruling that habitual drug users cannot be targeted under the law, which the Trump administration appealed.
The Trump administration argued that habitual drug users with firearms pose a risk to public safety, especially during encounters with law enforcement while impaired.
The administration cited phone records and travel to Iran as evidence of Hemani’s alleged ties to Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps and celebration of Qasem Soleimani’s death.

Hemani’s legal team challenged the historical basis of the law, noting that nearly half of US states have legalized recreational marijuana, suggesting a significant overlap between legal marijuana use and gun ownership.
Hunter Biden, the son of President Joe Biden, was previously convicted under the same law and later pardoned, adding political significance to the case.
The case is part of a broader legal debate over the scope of the Second Amendment and whether modern laws targeting drug users can be constitutionally upheld.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Supreme Court has agreed to review a federal law that prohibits certain drug users from possessing firearms, with the case centered on Ali Danial Hemani, a dual US-Pakistani citizen indicted in 2023 for possessing a firearm along with marijuana and cocaine. The prosecution claims Hemani’s habitual drug use poses a public safety risk, while a lower court and the 5th Circuit ruled that such a prohibition must have historical roots and cannot target habitual users. The Trump administration appealed the decision, arguing that impaired, habitual drug users with firearms present a grave danger to public safety, citing alleged ties to Iran and travel to Iran in connection with the death of Qasem Soleimani. Hemani’s legal team counters that the historical justification for the law is weak, especially given that nearly half of US states have legalized recreational marijuana, suggesting a significant overlap between legal marijuana use and gun ownership. The case has broader implications for Second Amendment rights, drug policy, and the balance between public safety and constitutional protections. President Joe Biden’s son, Hunter Biden, was previously convicted under the same law and later pardoned, adding political significance. The Supreme Court will likely hear arguments next year and issue a decision by the end of June 2026.
title: Justices Agree to Review Federal Law Banning Drug Users from Possessing Guns
